title: YouTube TV will still miss one major sports perk despite Disney deal
summary: Even though YouTube TV offers ESPN Unlimited, MLB.TV will be missing from the experience.
body: Credit: Joe Maring / Android Authority TL;DR YouTube TV subscribers wonโt have access to MLB.TV as part of ESNP Unlimited. MLBโs out-of-market streaming service has reportedly finalized a new agreement giving it a home inside the ESPN app. While YouTube TV subscribers now get ESPN Unlimited at no extra cost, MLB.TV will be available exclusively within the ESPN app and will likely require a separate subscription. After weeks of negotiations between YouTube and Disney, YouTube TV subscribers finally learned theyโll get ESPN Unlimited at no extra cost. Unfortunately, thereโs a catch. It looks like one of the most valuable sports packages still wonโt be part of the deal. According to a new report from Puckโs John Ourand , MLB.TV will not be part of the ESPN Unlimited experience on YouTube TV, even after it moves under ESPNโs umbrella next year.

title: Guiding Artemis: Brian Alpert Turns Lessons Learned Into Lunar Progress
summary: Brian Alpertโs path was always destined for the aerospace industry, but his journey turned toward NASAโs Johnson Space Center during his sophomore year in college. That was when Tricia Mack, who works in NASAโs Transportation Integration Office within the International Space Station Program, spoke โฆ
body: Brian Alpertโs path was always destined for the aerospace industry, but his journey turned toward NASAโs Johnson Space Center during his sophomore year in college. That was when Tricia Mack, who works in NASAโs Transportation Integration Office within the International Space Station Program, spoke to his aerospace seminar about planning spacewalks, training crews, and supporting operations from the Mission Control Center in Houston. Alpert was inspired to join the agency and later earned a spot as an engineering co-op student at Johnson. โMy first stop after new employee orientation was Triciaโs office,โ he said. Brian Alpert supports a spacewalk outside of the International Space Station from the Mission Control Center at Johnson Space Center in 2015. NASA/Bill Stafford Eighteen years later, Alpert is the cross-program integration deputy for NASAโs human landing system (HLS) โ the mode of transportation that will take astronauts to the lunar surface as part of the Artemis campaign. In his role, Alpert is responsible for coordinating with other Artemis programs, like the Orion Program, on issue resolution, joint agreements, data exchanges, hardware integration, and reviews. He alsโฆ

title: Suited Up for Science: NASA ER-2 Pilot Prepares for GEMx Flight
summary: NASA ER-2 pilot Kirt Stallings waits inside the transport vehicle moments before boarding the airborne science aircraft at NASAโs Armstrong Flight Research Center in Edwards, California, on Thursday, Aug. 21, 2025. Outside the window, the aircraft is being readied for a high-altitude mission supporโฆ
body: NASA/Christopher LC Clark NASA ER-2 pilot Kirt Stallings waits inside the transport vehicle moments before boarding the airborne science aircraft at NASAโs Armstrong Flight Research Center in Edwards, California, on Thursday, Aug. 21, 2025. Outside the window, the aircraft is being readied for a high-altitude mission supporting the Geological Earth Mapping Experiment (GEMx) , a multi-year NASAโU.S. Geological Survey campaign to map critical mineral resources across the Western United States. The GEMx team believes that undiscovered deposits of at least some of the 50 mineral commodities deemed essential to U.S. national security, to the tech industry, and to clean energy exist domestically, and modern mineral maps will support exploration by the private sector. In 2025 alone, the ER-2 flew 36 science missions, collecting more than seven billion measurements over 200 flight hours, contributing to the largest airborne surface mineralogy dataset ever gathered in a single NASA campaign. For this mission, pilots flew at approximately 65,000 feet altitude, requiring them to wear specially designed pressure suits to safely operate in the thin atmosphere. Image credit: NASA/Christopher LCโฆ
